review_detailed_main: The whole consept of the film is interesting and I haven't seen something similar but there was no story at all. Not even the classic horror story that someone dies and becomes a ghost or how someone becomes a killer.

review_title: How many of you went "BOOOOOOOO!!!" at that finish
The Open House: Just when I think Netflix is redeeming itself it releases something like this.....
review_detailed_main:
The Open House is a Netflix original movie and presently sits at no.55 on the IMDB bottom 100. So the IMDB community deems this to be the 55th worst movie ever made. I have to disagree, but there is no denying just how atrocious it is.

It tells the story of a mother and son who move into an open house after a tragedy befalls their family. As per the usual trope weird things begin to happen in the property.

The trouble is, well.................there are a lot of troubles but first of all the movie is..........wait, honestly I don't even know where to start here.

Awfully paced, dreadful characters you simply can't care about, a billion unanswered questions, the film ultimately goes nowhere at all! Basically the only redeeming features the film has are marginally decent cinematograpgy and a beautiful setting.

The Open House is fully deserving of all the poor ratings, it's the absolute pits.

The Good:

Beautiful location

The Bad:

Cliched to incredible levels

Unlikeable characters

Serves no purpose

Things I Learnt From This Movie:

Nothing, in fact I'm pretty sure it caused brain leakage so I've probably forgot some stuff

Most of the 1 star reviews articulate the problem really well but if you're still unclear allow me to communicate it in another way.

Imagine you walked into your living room and saw Frank Sinatra playing world of warcraft. Then your neighbour came round several times and said some weird stuff to you. Then your cat takes a dump in your bed and moos at you. Then you start singing the lyrics to YMCA while Eiffel 65 is playing 'I'm blue' in the background

So you must be asking yourself, What was the relevance of sinatra and why world of warcraft? Why did my neighbour come around and what did they say? Why did your cat moo and why sing YMCA to a different tune?

The truth is...no reason at all. None of it related to anything. Pointless. No connection. Nothing

review_title: The Worst Movie I Have Watched In A Long Time!
review_detailed_main: What??? There was no ending?? It was pointless to even watch! A waste of time for the viewer.

review_title: Spoiler Alerts Don't Matter Because There Is Nothing To Spoil
review_detailed_main:
Good job Netflix! You bought total crap! After watching this I can't help but feel like the "writers" of this trainwreck are sitting in their beanbag chairs and taking turns patting each other on the back. Instead of congratulating themselves they should be taking script writing classes. This was the laziest piece of crap that I have seen in a VERY long time. "Oh! We have a great idea for a movie!...I mean...we don't have any structure and we don't have a clue how to finish it...but maybe people will think we're geniuses for just phoning in the entire ending of the movie!"

Listen...there are no spoiler alerts here. This movie is a complete waste of time. If these two morons ever hope to make another movie...maybe they should learn something about structure...plot...climax. I feel like this movie was written on a napkin at a Denny's and then left on the table and the busboy decided to make it.

It's just awful. Stay away. And pray they never make another film in their lives. There are too many talented writers and directors out there to waste any time on these two.

There...I said it.

review_title: Never been so angry or disappointed in a film...EVER
review_detailed_main:
I completely jinxed this movie by saying how good it was halfway through.

I've seen some pretty horrendous horror films in my lifetime, but you expect them to be horrendous because they are what they say on the tin. Cheap and easy.

This film is the opposite, it's deceptive and not in a "ahhh wasn't expecting that" sort of way. More a feeling of being completely ripped off and dissatisfied kinda way. We honestly really enjoyed a good majority of this film, so many things that look like they're building up to a really good twist at the end. Mysterious characters, red herrings, things that could be linked together in a really cool way.

How naive and utterly wrong we were.

There is no point to this film. Literally, why was this film made? It's like they employed a really good writer for the first half of the film who put together a brilliant structure and then some idiot decided to take over and realised he/she was in over their head. By the last shot I was honestly screaming "DO NOT ROLL CREDITS" and my sister had to restrain me when the goddam screen went black.

This review may seem extra, but I have never been so angry, frustrated and disappointed by a potentially great film.

I urge you not to waste your time.

I have to go cool off and try and forget the fact I ever watched this piece of rubbish.

I really don't know what happened here. It started off well, but then it just kind of fizzled. The acting wasn't bad, but the writing was. Certainly nothing original about the plot. I was really expecting more from this movie. Overall its just 90 minutes of my life that I can never get back.It almost seems like they just ran out of money and decided to just go ahead and end it.It will leave you unsatisfied and with a bunch of questions that will likely never get answered. Netflix must have acquired this movie for a bargain basement price not caring about their subscribers. Please no more recommendations Netflix

review_title: A total BS of a movie
review_detailed_main:
I thought the movie started really good, building up to something interesting...but boy was I wrong.

Still wanna say that the lead characters were very good and acted reliably.

After like 85% of the movie I was looking forward to see how the writers was gonna tie at least some of the knots together...but boy was I wrong again.

We, the audience are left in total darkness without an answer to a single thing what so ever.

Hmm, getting tired of writing this review now so I'll stop here and go on to watch another hopefully much much more satisfying movie.

To all you moviebuffs out there...don't bother with this one. /J

I am not surprised by the low reviews, and the low score, I have to say I enjoyed it. I get that it doesn't have a black and white conclusion, that ambiguity in the end of a film can irritate some, but I'd like to highlight The Strangers, a similar outcome, but a masterclass in movie making, and while The Open House doesn't even come close it raises a few questions. The ending was probably done in that way to allow for a second, and I wouldn't be shocked to see an Open House Part 2 made.

Solid performances, Dylan Minnette, who's always pretty good put in a solid performance, I thought the scenes where he lashed out in anger to his mother about his father's death were very well played out, films so often go way over the top, this had a sense of realism.

When you think that the budget for this film was $100,000 I think it should be applauded, many films with budgets many times that size fail in so many ways, this was a good hour and a half of escapism.

It's not to be taken too seriously, and we didn't get many answers, but that's life.I quite enjoyed it.

review_title: Worst movie... Ever. Like ever ever.

...awful.

Dylan Minnette definitely has a nice future ahead as long as he never does a film like this again. It's never a good thing when you want the main characters to die 30 minutes into the movie. Horribly written characters who were just mean and the story itself, if you want to even call it a story as it was completely plotless. At one point somehow the bad guy, or depending one how one looks at it the good guy, decides to take a persons contacts out, to conceal his identity. I guess he was to lazy to just wear a mask, instead he manually takes the guys contacts out. I have no clue how this movie ever got made, it is that bad. My twelve year old could come up with a better movie then this. I could pull out my IPhone, and randomly grab a couple of hobos from the rail yard and make a better movie than this drivel. This movie was so bad, and such a waste of time I'm considering canceling my Netflix subscription of 5 years, and filing a lawsuit for the time I will never get back watching this garbage. I've been watching horror movies for 33 years, and I can honestly say this is the worst horror movie I've ever watched, it is also the worst movie I've ever watched period. I've been an imdb member since it originated, and this is the first review I've ever posted. I don't want any other person to have to suffer through this garbage like I did. Let me save you two hours you will never get back. Mr. Angel, and Ms.Coote please do everyone a favor...Please do not ever make another film again!!!

review_title: Why so many 1 ratings? This was a decent movie.
The poster child for how NOT to write a horror movie.
Ends up being a frustrating watch
review_detailed_main: There are some good Netflix exclusive movies out there, but there are also a number of poor efforts, and "The Open House" is one of those stumbles. While it is definitely a bad movie, I didn't find it quite as bad as most IMDb users here have found it. The production values were good for what had to be a non blockbuster budget. Also, the first half of the movie does have a little mood and eeriness. But otherwise, the movie pretty much screws things up. I could live with the setup being somewhat familiar, but the execution of the setup is quite badly done. Most of the movie (especially in the first half) unfolds at a REALLY slow pace, with no real strong thrills or plot turns to keep the viewer actively engaged. The lead characters also seem very dim-witted, not seeing that something is seriously wrong before things turn very serious. Also, while the movie seems to be setting up for some surprise plot twists and turns, NOTHING about this setup pays off in the end. There is no real explanation as to what is happening and why, and what we have seen before the ending seems just to have been padding before the very unsatisfying conclusion. While I will admit that the movie could have been a lot worse, I really can't see it entertaining any particular viewer.
I hope the people that made this movie never make another movie again.

review_title: Netflix, why? Don't waste your time
review_detailed_main:
I've watched some really bad movies on Netflix like No Mercy but The Open House is the worst movie I've watched. At least No Mercy had a beginning middle and end but The Open House has a beginning and middle but no end. It just leads you to nothing and you are left feeling "What the F?!"

The movie starts like out any C movie on Netflix, some tragedy and then the main characters have to make a decision they don't really want to but being financially strapped have to. Then creepy things start to happen and there is violence but then it just abruptly stops there. It makes no sense and is very frustrating. The viewer becomes invested in the characters. The actors actually do the best the can and the acting is not bad. But the characters are one dimensional. We don't ever really get to the know the wife and son.

The movie feels like it was edited with a guillotine. There are scenes put together that don't make sense. For instance the son complains they moved away from his friends and he didn't want to go but there are no scenes prior to that of him feeling this way. We straight up have a conversation between the wife and her sister about moving to the mountain home and then voila they are driving to the mountain home.

Does Netflix think because it is spending loads of money on several movies like Bright that it can just have really bad movies to fill the line up of movies? Don't waste your time.

review_title: Decent Scary Movie, despite what the other reviews say.

review_detailed_main:
Saw 'The Open House' on Netflix a while ago, being fond of horror/thriller regardless of budget (even if not my favourite genre) and being intrigued somewhat by the idea. Being behind on my film watching and reviewing, with a long to watch and review list that keeps getting longer, it took me a while to get round to reviewing it.

Unfortunately, despite not reading any reviews purposefully before watching, am going to have to agree with all the reviewers who hated 'The Open House'. A film that started off pretty good, but ran out of steam very quickly and rapidly got worse by a second half that makes one not want to keep watching. Never judge a film without seeing the whole thing and wanted to give 'The Open House', so gave it a fair chance.

As said, 'The Open House' started off pretty promising.

Dylan Minnette and Piercey Dalton give surprisingly good performances considering the material, especially Minnette. The soundtrack has some nice moments (i.e. "Silent Night"), when it isn't being intrusive and annoying.

However, so much brings 'The Open House' down. The rest of the cast struggle to do much with so little to do and the direction is so phoned in and pedestrian, one gets the sense that the director showed no interest in the film at all. Too much of the soundtrack is intrusive and annoying, made worse by the excessive and obvious sound effects that just cheapens the mood. The film looks drab generally and like it was made in haste.

Where 'The Open House' most underwhelms is the writing and story. The writing is incredibly lazy, it's awkward in dialogue, very confused as a result of not tying things up or going into full detail and doesn't feel complete. The story suffers from a very limp pace, apparent early on and gets slower and slower until an interminably dragged out second half. It further suffers from feeling too much like a short film stretched out with a lot of useless padding. A few of the characters are reasonably likeable but the inconsistent and illogical motivations bring them down.

For a film billed as a horror, though it's more a thriller with horror elements, there is very little interesting and nothing remotely scary. They are too few and are far too predictable, anaemic and weakly timed to make impact, with the dull pacing and obvious sound effects cheapening them significantly. In terms of the thriller elements, 'The Open House' doesn't engage let alone thrill, the start intrigued by feels wasted by how quickly everything runs out of steam. Worst of all is the ending, which is so abrupt, unresolved and incomplete that one struggles to even consider it an ending, the film just ends and leaves one scratching their heads in confusion and feeling cheated.

Overall, the potential was there but the execution far from was. Really bad, unless you're curious about seeing it it's best to keep this house closed. 2/10 Bethany Cox

I gotta admit I was as annoyed with the ending as most of the low star reviewers at first. Then I slept on it and woke up still thinking about this movie. I realized that the ending just fit the overall atmosphere of the story. There is SO much that is left unsaid and it dawned on me that it is by design. That was the whole point. We simply don't know for sure and probably never will, unless there is a sequel. I've decided I'm okay with this and it's made me apreciate the movie in a whole new way.

I have my own theory as to what happened. If you pay attention, there are quite a few clues throughout the movie that point to a very likely conclusion.

I hate that I will never be certain, but there are a million other movies I can watch if I crave that kind of closure. This is clearly not one of those movies. It made me think outside the cookie cutter thriller/horror box. It made me question my expectations. It made me realize that the reason we get upset by these frustrating, anti-climatic endings is because of our innate need to control and correct imbalance and injustice. Sometimes life is just unfair, bad things happen and we'll never know why.

Give it a chance. The movie is decent. Not a masterpiece by any stretch, but well worth a watch.

review_title: A waste of time to watch.
review_detailed_main:
'THE OPEN HOUSE': Two and a Half Stars (Out of Five)

A horror flick about a teenager and his mother who move into a house that appears to be haunted by mysterious forces. The movie stars Dylan Minnette, Piercey Dalton, Sharif Atkins, Patricia Bethune and Aaron Abrams. It was written, directed and co-produced by rookie filmmakers Matt Angel and Suzanne Coote (who also play small parts in the film), and it was released by Netflix through it's streaming site. The movie is well shot, and acted in my opinion, but it's also completely pointless, and a waste of time to watch.

Logan Wallace (Minnette) is a teenager with dreams of being a champion runner. Then his father is struck and killed by a car, while Logan is watching. He and his mother, Naomi (Dalton), move into her sister's house, while it's in the process of being sold. They soon realize that there might be powerful supernatural forces there, that are unhappy with their presence. The movie is a pretty routine horror/thriller flick, but (like I said) the production values are decent, and Minnette gives a good enough performance in the lead. The story, and character development, isn't horrible, until the end of the movie. That's when I felt like the whole film was kind of a complete waste of time. Up until then though, I didn't feel that negatively about the movie.

Do you like confusing movies? That are not giving you any real resolution but let you in the dark and leave your questions unanswered? Well you are in luck. This movie was made for you. Try not to get distracted by the lack of emotional attachment to the characters or a relatively weak script overall (that's dialog and characters).

Most of it will probably will leave you cold (no pun intended) and the trippy ending is not really satisfying. On the other hand, you could say points for not daring to be different in the end. Until then though, many cliches and jump scares ... if that floats your boat. Cinematography and generally technically sound (I've seen worse)
The movie just,,,,ends,,,we don't know who did it, why they did it, anything???? total waste of time

review_title: It's pretty bad, but it's not 3.4/10 bad
review_detailed_main:
It's pretty clear that 'The Open House' is failing to connect with people in a positive way based on its 3.4/10 score on IMDb. Seeing that I went into it expecting something pretty terrible. Now, while I can understand that this film has faults a plenty, I can't quite grasp it having a score that low. Let's get into some analysis.

The problems the movie possesses are as follows. Firstly, it's a bore. There are long periods of the film where it feels like nothing of significance is happening. Now that might not be entirely true when you find out what is actually going on at the end of the film, however the audience not being let in on this information is still going to be bored and uninterested. And therein lies probably the biggest flaw the movie has. There is a genuine threat to these people in the movie, but the audience has no idea about it. How can that ever be considered a good idea to have in your movie? Finally the amount of red herrings this film has that ultimately lead to absolutely nothing is absurd. There was a chance to be clever along the way, but the film makers just completely by-passed that option.

So why didn't I hate this film as much as everyone else? A lot of people are going to hate this movie for its ending and the path it chose to take. I actually respect it for it. At least, I respect the idea. The execution left a lot to be desired. The idea though was actually quite bold and attempting to be unique. I also liked that it didn't fall into the lazy category of slipping into the supernatural side of things, although there is at least one dream sequence is the laziest of all types of film making. So no this isn't a good film, but I also don't agree with its score being as low as it is.

review_title: Excellent, if you are smart enough to get the story.
review_detailed_main: I don't want to just right out tell you the whole plot like many do their reviews. I am surprised with such negative reviews. I liked it, and it made sense, you can figure out what happened pretty early if you take in all the clues. It really builds and maintains. If you like a slow creeping horror, that makes you analyze exactly what is going on in the then this movie is for you. I would say that Patricia Bethune performance was quite lordly, if you catch my drift, and that the main characters (mother and child) are quite good souls, that makes this film a crash hit!

-3 points for the nonsense the mom had in this movie. I gave it a 7/10 for the rest of the movie written. I found it to be story that left room for interpretation - somewhat like life - you don't know what you're getting but you know there's something you're to get from it. Yes, the mom was insensitive at times to her son who had more commonsense than she and yes, the story had no ending but that's where the interpretation comes in at. It left room for a broad discussion i.e. who done it, why and who was involved. Should every story have an ending or should we just allow ourselves as screenplay viewers to be open to personal or group discussion. It's not a question, it's rhetorical. It certainly leaves room for a sequel. :)

Then movies on to the boy's mother and her son moving to a large secluded house belonging to her sister so they can sell the property. Many jump scares in the home with no connection to the deceased husband or the sister. The boy has nightmares of the father in the home but with no understanding of why his ghost appears in this home. Then an intruder kidnaps the mother and son and tortures them with no apparent motive. Sketchy small town characters that we have no idea what their connection to the home is. And finally the ending leaves us completely in the dark. No resolution. We end up knowing nothing more than how the film started. Seriously Netflix? I know not every original can be a winner, but this film feels like a lousy cut and paste of an edit of a much larger film. Did Netflix servers run out of storage space that they had to butcher the film to make it fit onto Netflix's hard drives?

I should have taken it as a bad sign in the opening of the movie when the son is training as a runner (with hopes of being an Olympian) and he and his parents are raving about his 5:07 time. What length of distance is this amazing 5:07???? They never said how far he was running, and I thought, "well, it can't be a mile time, because everyone knows that it was a big deal many decades ago when the 4 minute mile was broken." But guess what? Later, it comes up again - as his running goals are significant to him - and YES, it IS a mile time! How is it that the writing-directing team, the lead actor, anyone on the entire filmmaking team didn't catch this major gaffe?

Basically, this movie consists of a bunch of long shots pushing in ominously trying to make us scared, but it fails to deliver much of a story.

review_title: Who ever made this never again

review_detailed_main:
I am not surprised by the low reviews, and the low score, I have to say I enjoyed it. I get that it doesn't have a black and white conclusion, that ambiguity in the end of a film can irritate some, but I'd like to highlight The Strangers, a similar outcome, but a masterclass in movie making, and while The Open House doesn't even come close it raises a few questions. The ending was probably done in that way to allow for a second, and I wouldn't be shocked to see an Open House Part 2 made.

Solid performances, Dylan Minnette, who's always pretty good put in a solid performance, I thought the scenes where he lashed out in anger to his mother about his father's death were very well played out, films so often go way over the top, this had a sense of realism.

When you think that the budget for this film was $100,000 I think it should be applauded, many films with budgets many times that size fail in so many ways, this was a good hour and a half of escapism.

It's not to be taken too seriously, and we didn't get many answers, but that's life.

review_title: Terrible 3rd Act. Lets the whole film down.
review_detailed_main:
I thought the first hour of this film was ok. Nice slow burn. And random characters added throughout as the possible 'intruder'. Sure the main characters do some stupid stuff to keep the plot moving forward, but for the most part I let it slide, because I was still entertained.

The last 20 minutes however was just awful. I expected the movie to ramp up and get exciting with the mother & son making the intruder wish he'd picked another house ... but no, there was no fighting back. They both die and he leaves. And he was no one. They didn't even show his face, which was kind of stupid. Make it the crazy Neighbors husband or something. Anything but the nothing you chose.

Also, hire some stunt people/stunt doubles. I know the film was made on the cheap, but that 3rd act needed some actual action and there was nothing. They couldn't even smash a table or have someone falling down the stairs - the basics. It was so dodgy.

I'd recommend not watching. You'll just be disappointed.

review_title: I'm honestly dumbfounded that people got paid to make this movie.
review_detailed_main: This is my first time reviewing a movie. I felt compelled to write this review for the common good of the Netflix community. This movie made no sense whatsoever. No questions were answered, the plot had so many holes in it, and the script seemed ridiculous. I was not convinced with any of the dialogue; it all seemed canned and unbelievable. The music was good at times. But what in the name of all things holy was up with those scenes with the suspenseful music, where nothing even happened? For example, at one point, suspenseful music crescendoed while Logan walked in the basement. The camera focuses on a bunch of wood, and then the scene ends. What the hell? Was that wood supposed to be a foreshadowing of something? At another time, intense music builds up and ends with the camera just focusing on the woods outside. There were multiple instances of this. It's like the directors went to film school, learned about suspenseful build-ups, but completely fell asleep while the instructor covered how to use them. There has to be, like, a reason! I'm thoroughly astounded that Netflix picked this up. You mean to tell me that a Netflix executive watched this, liked it, and made the conscious decision to pay for this movie? I honestly can't believe that. My honest (but maybe a bit crazy) suspicion is that this movie was made by artificial intelligence. A crude, experimental AI algorithm designed to configure a set of factors such as sets of characters, plot points, sets of dialogue and such, into a set amount of time. And the Netflix community is unwittingly the user testing group. There's no other serious explanation. The dialogue was so forced and unrealistic. The characters weren't believable. The plot, especially, was incoherent. AI is breaking into everything, and it has to start somewhere. If this really was AI, at least in some capacity, calling the shots as a director, I'd say it was a good first effort. But if this was an actual human production, may God have mercy on these producers' and directors' souls and careers.

review_detailed_main: I just wasted an hour and a half of my life. I do not recommend unless you'll spend the whole movie on instagram going trough memes or something.

I am not sure what all the hate on this movie is really about- especially considering the genre of horror movies that lives on Netflix is dismal at best. I am a huge horror fan, and I have seen some really bad horror movies. This is NOT one of them.

Now on to my review about this movie. I will really focus on what worked, I won't even really comment on what didn't work since everyone is spewing it too much any way.

I really enjoyed the initial sense of confusion the film brought, is it a ghost? Or is it a killer? Were they set up by the sister? What is with the neighbor? Will they live?

These are all great senses of confusion the filmmakers brought to the table in a horror flick, you shouldn't know where the film is going and it creates a great deal of confession as a viewer- which I really enjoy. These types of atmosphere for horror are rare, but when done right- can keep you watching it till the end since you don't have a feeling you figured it out at any time.

My favorite aspect is the unexplained backstory- Halloween (78) is a great example of why someone (or something) can be so scary- because we don't understand it. We shouldn't need backstories explained out for why someone kills people in scary movies. Again this is a horror movie, if you want that level of detail- check out MindHunter. This is about creating a villain that is so uncomfortable- you don't understand them at all. (Side note on this: this movie is riddled with homages to the original Halloween). And no- you as a viewer should NOT be connecting with a horror villain like this in order to enjoy the movie, you would feel confused and weirded out. That is how the filmmakers want you to feel.

Lastly- this movie did a great job making everything look and sound great. I think the score was fantastic and the locations were beautiful. Even down to the small shots of the basement tunnels.

My main and only complaint is this film does require a larger sense of need to suspend reality. Although- I can't think of how many times I lose my cellphone and "swear" I just left it plugged in. I think this movie tries to show you a sense of confusion within the characters that makes you feel bad for them. They are not in their "right state of mind" to begin with, however- most people don't call the police or move when you have misplaced something. How many times have you left a light on and swore you turned it off? It creates this sense of how do you even keep track of those things when large issues are on your mind? IE money and family death. I see it too often in people who don't usually watch horror movies: "I would never go back upstairs".

Overall, this was decent. It didn't have any hype that I knew of, I just turned it on and watched it. It's fun and has a lot of moments that keep you guessing- until the end. I also didn't find the end confusing at all. I this the final shot made it pretty clear what happened and what will happen again.

review_title: Some good acting without any good writing
review_detailed_main:
Very little was explained in this movie at any time.

The setup was clean enough, and the early actors gave us hints as to family dynamics and the challenges the main characters were facing.

Soon something changes the course of their lives, and we proceed from there. When the family moves to a house that one of their sisters owns, they have to clear out on Sundays because the realtor is holding open houses then. Hence comes the title; fine.

The problems with this suspenseful ride were twofold. First, a few foolish things happen that seem implausible, but you can forgive that since the characters are struggling with some heavy issues (no spoilers here).

But far worse, the ending to this movie made NO sense at all, and when you see what the writers must have considered a reveal, it reveals nothing at all, either.

The acting was fair, even if the producers didn't develop the characters as much as they did the scenery. But the reasons behind it all were never given, and how can you care about characters or a story if it all means nothing in the end?

That was bad.

Real bad.

So bad that created my first IMBD account explicitly to come here to let you know not to bother watching it, because, it was that bad. So many reasons not to watch it, I can't list them all. But let's start with: 1. Weak plot.

2. No fear or horror or terror involved.

3. Obscene amount of "but that doesn't make sense" moments. The kind that make you pick up your phone and start scrolling because you check out of the movie.

4. Mom looks like she literally dying the entire time (probably not a reason NOT to watch, but like.. why?) 5. Back story was pointless. Utterly pointless. It did not lend to any emotional nuance or plot twist or anything. Just wasted film time.

Watch something else. Catch up on One Piece... You know you have like, 397 episodes left.

review_title: True imagining of a real horror
review_detailed_main: The beauty of this movie is the reality it depicts. The noble premise, which I thought brilliant, is to take two utterly ordinary and defenceless people, driven by tragedy and circumstances to a huge rambling mansion, which, again by circumstance, they are forced to leave vulnerable and open to the public for long periods. This defencelessness is heightened by the lead's terrible eyesight, being effectively blind without contacts or glasses. This is very sophisticated drama, and the actors and director manage this with consummate skill. However, such realism, which by its very nature can be time-consuming to portray, may well not be everyone's cup of tea. And the length of the buildup does tend to immunise the viewer from a lot of the scares that repeat. It did for me, but not for my brother, whom jumped twice as often as I did. The tragedy mentioned is revealed only in the behaviour of the leads, a delicate thing, and why I give this piece a high score, with only one flashback late in the movie to make the circumstance specific. That was a plus for me. There is very little gore or splatter and certainly no special effects. It is an effective journey into an ultimate and very real horror, but it is also a very sad reflection on tragedy and vulnerability. I loved the message of this movie. This is an intelligent picture.

Classic cheap jump scares, stupid dreams that they make you belive is real and a lot of really stupid decisions... The ending was one of the worst endings i have ever seen and it doesn't excplain anything at all... Do not waste your time watching this horrible movie! Netflix has proven to me that they can make one of the best TV Shows in the world but this movie was just the worst!

Nice flick for the most part, but at its conclusion it leads to a rather bland and mundane feeling of nothingness or irrelevance, that this movie will be completely gone and forgotten from our heads immediately thereafter.

Everyone tried so HARD..acting (despite the paltry material) is quite good. Cinematography is A+. Beautiful set interiors of a gorgeous house-practically-mansion makes you want to go out house-buying. Problem is, what you have here is a cliche machine, churning out cliche nonsense after cliche nonsense same as you've seen so often in every suspense/horror movie you've every seen, that it makes you moan out-loud knowing what's coming 10 minutes before it happens. If you enjoy those long, interminablely slow tracking shots following a character walking and walking and walking and looking and looking (almost always with a flashlight) accompanied by the cliche scary music only to have an overly loud musical "bang," character jumps and yells -- you've got that here over and over again until you feel like you're stuck in a time-loop twilight zone episode...all of a sudden you realize it is YOU who are in a nightmare from which you can't wake up.

You have seen all of this before, but what's worse, because the characters ARE likable and because you want at lease a reasonable resolution for them -- not to mention a reasonable, intelligent explanation of all the hokum for yourself -- you keep watching; alas, resolutions or explanations for the characters or for you as a reward for sticking with this lump of regurgitated trash is DENIED. What you are subjected to ikn the last reel, completely out of nowhere are violence and torture...and then an end credit roll that will make your blood boil. I won't reveal the ending, but all I will say is, it's not satisfying on ANY level; it resolves nothing and left me, anyway, wanting to find this director and break everyone of HIS damn fingers.

Bottom line, it's an unfortunate waste of the talents of everyone involved...but then, they all got paid; you didn't...and trust me, your time and talents are worth more than this scam of a movie. S K I P I T !

review_title: I've never hated a movie so much in my entire life.. until this!
review_detailed_main:
Oh, Netflix, how've you made a huge mistake. The first time I saw this trailer, I thought it had a neat concept. It had the potential of a great mystery. But, oh boy, was I dead wrong!

The movie starts with Dylan Minette (I won't bother you with the character's name) whose father has a tragic accident as he witnessed it happened. The family has financial problems which prompts them to move. His mother's sister offers them an open house she has yet to sale in the meantime until they get back on their feet. As soon as they start staying there, weird things start to happen.

The first few minutes starts well, but then descends into a black pit of turd. Why do I find it so horrible? I mean, the actors are fine, the camerawork's great, the cinematography's beautiful. It's just the execution and the storytelling.are so unfathomably stupid, clichéd, and have been done to death. False jump scares; weird, possible red herrings; characters who are oblivious to what's happening around them, who does stupid things. By the end, I was just laughing because of how ridiculous the conclusion is.

The only saving graces are Dylan Minette and Piercey Dalton. They really tried to convince us with their conflict that stems from their grief. Their dramatic moments were the only highlight of this movie, which are so few and far in between.

It's infuriating to see such hackneyed work that looks gorgeous and has some great acting. If this were to be released in theaters, it would flop so bad. Don't bother wasting your time on this.

review_title: A very interesting try and exceptional good result
review_detailed_main:
Despite the most ratings here, I think that this film provided a new approach to the common horror/thriller movies: Precicely because of the minimalistic way to suggest and not to "cheap" exposing of everything and the open interpretations to several occurences, the viewer stays always on and after the end keeps thinking.

And no, the typical "american" film with "heroes" who win and thrive at the end is not here to find. At last something new, different and above all, more realistic. It is not a fairy tale, it could happen to you.

The overal sound of the film is fantastic assumed you have a descent home theater unit, the photography even good and the overal result very satisfying.

review_title: Scary movie with interesting plot twists
review_detailed_main:
I'm glad I didn't read these reviews before watching the movie. The reviews truly don't do justice to this film. It deserves a much higher rating.

The acting is quite impressive, and the plot is incredibly unpredictable. Some of the movie characters were clearly designed to deceive the audience, and it definitely worked, at least for me.

What's most remarkable is how genuinely terrifying this movie is! To be honest, I believed until the very last minute that the film would conclude differently, and it was quite a shock to see just how mistaken I was.

While I'm not typically a fan of these types of movie endings, I find it refreshing to have one that deviates from the mainstream. It undoubtedly leaves you with a sense of unease, which I consider a sign of a great movie.

This is my first review on IMDB... I have watched some awful films in my time but this one... I fell asleep through it the first time and thought I'd give it another chance. Well, what a complete waste of my time!!! This film had really good potential even though its all been done before! There was a bit of suspense and one part really made me cringe! However there is literally 0 point in the film! I wish I had checked the IMDB rating before wasting my life on it! Who was the killer? Why couldnt we see him? Was it to do with the dads death? Who the bloody hell was that woman? So many unanswered questions! One of the worst endings imaginable! Honestly do not bother wasting your time! This is the only Netflix Original that has disappointed me. Netflix... what were you thinking???

Movie started good and had an interesting plot, but none of the seemingly meaningful events and happenings wound up playing any part in the movie at all, it just stopped with the credits rolling and without any answers to what happened or what you had just watched.

Watch something else, literally anything else, watch Shrek again, you know you want to!
Come on!!! The ending! Really! What tha! unbelievable! Leave people hanging! Geez! Uh!
Slow to pick up, not really scary, coulda been a better sentimental movie, we hated it

First of all, if you really need to know every detail in a movie, dont watch this one because you wont like it as the other users. yes there was some weird scenes that you might not fully understand but on the whole it was not a 3,2 point movie. it makes you feel their terror and you feel the tension. but although the ending doesnt give you that person, it has some little clues that you may guess what happend..

review_title: No Beginning. No middle, and no end
13 reasons why the movie isn't THAT bad
One of the worst films I have seen in my life
review_detailed_main:
This movie was so bad, I will not even spend any time writing a traditional review. it just isn't worth it. Plus, it seems like this movie is getting hammered by terrible reviews from everyone who is unfortunate enough to see it. So, instead of a review, I have a few questions;

1. To the writers responsible for this abomination; have you ever seen a movie before? Do you understand basic story structure, and how every successful story has to have a clear beginning, middle and end? Where was your road map as to how this movie was supposed to unfold? I am just struggling to understand what the thought processes were here.

2. The movie had everything going for it; Decent premise, a great trailer, an extremely talented cast, a nice soundtrack. How did it derail so profoundly, to the point of it almost appearing intentional? No one releases garbage like this and is proud to have their name prominently displayed in the credits, so what gives?

3. If this is a suspense/thriller, why all of the jump scares? It's too tame to be a horror film and not smart enough to be a real thriller, so whom may I ask was the intended audience? There is salty language, nudity and some disturbing scenes, but everything rolls out like a Teen Nick special. Who were you targeting, and were you aware that you were going to fail everyone with this project?

4. Lastly, what in the name of all that is sweet and pure in the world was the conclusion of the movie about? I would not even call it a real conclusion, as nothing is truly resolved, but were the film makers attempting to evoke a vastly superior film (Funny Games), failed miserably, and said, "You know what? The movie is done. Just release it as is. Someone is bound to like it"? I cannot for the life of me think of a single person I would recommend this film to. I just wouldn't do that to anyone.

This is one of those rare movies that doesn't accomplish anything, which makes it that much more embarrassing as it had all the cards stacked in its favor. The writers should be ashamed that they unleashed this dirty diaper onto Netflix, and Netflix itself should be publicly shamed for allowing it to soil their service. One of the worst movies I have EVER seen, don't even bother watching it out of curiosity. Please, do not waste your precious time like I have.

Don't even try to. No plot whatsoever. Only some scares without any context. NO PLOT. NONE. ZERO. THIS BS OF A MOVIE SHOULD BE ILLEGAL. THERE'S PORN OUT THERE BETTER DONE THAN THIS ATROCITY. Spoilers? Spoilers to what? What plot should I spoil? There is no plot, just 2 hours of nothing at all. Pathetic, literally. Just don't, please.

review_title: Movie is promising at first but the last 10 mins was horrible!

review_detailed_main: I was all ready to give this fright flick 9 stars. It held me on the edge of my seat...right up until the last 2 minutes. The description read "Following a tragedy, a mother and her teenage son move to a relative's vacant vacation home where eerie and unexplained forces conspire against them." This is what's meant by 'truth in advertising'. Not only are the forces unexplained to the characters, but also to us, the audience. What were the producers and writers thinking? Did they not have any clue how to put closure to the story? What an insult to every viewer who stuck through this movie to the bitter end...and I am one bitter viewer. In actuality, the movie is a solid 8 or 9 stars, but 8 or 9 stars are taken away due to the pathetic ending. Inexcusable, inconsiderate and an embarrassment.

I wouldn't say this is.... I think I can safely say we've all..... The ending really..... The acting was g..... The directing...mmmm....wellll....

Are we seeing a pattern here? Yes. That's how the movie ended.

.............

There is no plot, no story, no explanation of absolutely anything and everything that happens is pointless. Build ups that go nowhere, mysteries that are created for no reason and are abandoned and unecessary drama in a movie that is not the worst I've ever seen but sure as hell is the emptiest. Just close the house!

review_title: Open House? More like Open Ended...
Have an open mind to watch the Open House.
review_detailed_main:
I was minding my own business, trying to fill a quota of things to watch when Netflix suggested this movie. I figured, "ooh, a scary movie on a Saturday night, starring Dylan Minette (13 Reasons Why), 'Don't Breathe' was good, let's go!"

The trailer says, "You can't lock out what's already inside." Maybe we'll get lucky and this will be sort of like the iconic 'Scream' franchise. We follow Logan and his mother as they are forced to move to his aunt's big house in a very secluded location. The only catch is they have to leave for the most part of every Sunday because there's an open house where potential buyers come in and out inspecting the place. Big house, out every Sunday, seems harmless enough, right?

When they get back, strange things start to happen like doors closing, things getting moved, and noises from places where there shouldn't be. At this point, everyone becomes a suspect, the kooky neighbor, the over-friendly store attendant, the plumber, the cops, and even Logan himself. Halfway through the movie I confidently said I've got the invader figured out and was just riding it out until the movie ends. Boy was I wrong.

I won't spoil it for you but you have to wait until the end credits to figure out who the invader is. Like literally, you have to read the cast credits. Then it's up to you as to how you will react. A Forbes review got pissed off, it has a 3.2/10 rating in IMDB, while I just laughed and figured to just charge it to Netflix's aggressive expansion for content in 2017-18 (see The Ritual, 1922, Gerald's Game and Hush.) As long as you don't have a lot of expectations and you have 90 minutes to waste, you might actually enjoy it.

No spoilers because there is nothing to spoil! Don't waste your time. Every single persons review couldn't be more accurate. The movie doesn't have a plot. It's just a bunch of random things happening for no reason ultimately to lead to the main characters deaths. Who was he killer? What was the motive?? Noting was explained. I honestly feel so let down. All of the "significant" parts had NOTHING to do with the entire movie.
I wish i could get back my hour and a half wasted watching this garbage, one of the worst movies i have seen in my entire life

review_title: Better watch the trailer NOT the movie
review_detailed_main: There is no story at all. Its a garbage garbage garbage garbage

review_title: Are there going to be any home invasion movies with an original plot?
review_detailed_main: As far as I can tell, if you've seen one home invasion movie, you've seen 'em all. "The Open House" is no exception. I couldn't tell what the point of it was. Totally empty.

review_title: Horribly Written, Terrible Movie with an Idiotic Ending
review_detailed_main:
I'm really getting sick of The Netflix Fodder School of Fimmaking. You don't have to understand basic storytelling they teach in Creative Writing 101. All you have to do is have a camera, some people to film and a place to shoot it. No need for story, whatsoever.

This movie spends almost all it's time pretending it's a supernatural thriller, changes genres right at the end and then leaves you hanging. This is not because the writer was clever and wanted to create a genre bending movie, it's because they didn't have f#ck of an idea what they were doing.

The other title I give these horrible attempts at movie making is 'participation trophy cinema'. This is the result of giving children trophies for accomplishing nothing. They grew up thinking they were 'special' and all they had to do is show up and world was there to kiss their underachieving ass. Well, they should've f#cking applied themselves because we don't deserve to be subjected to their lack of discipline and initiative.

Do NOT watch this. It is a waste of your time and the creators didn't have any idea what they were doing and should never have been encouraged to make movies.

We're in the risky month of January once again and when it comes to watching new releases in entertainment, it's usually a coin toss as to whether or not a movie will actually be good. Ever since Netflix began to release original films, I've found myself holding out hope that fantastic independent films will slowly begin to make their way onto streaming services, instead of failing at the box office. Well, if one of Netflix's most recent films in The Open House is any indication, then we're still a very long way from something like that ever happening. Not only is this one of the most non-scary horror films that I've seen in recent memory, but it's also one of the worst films in general that I've seen in recent memory. People talk about how bad a movie is, but sometimes it just has to be seen to be believed. Now streaming, here's why I think you should check this movie out just to see how bad it truly is.

Starring Dylan Minnette and Piercey Dalton star in The Open House, a film that (after a tragic event) follows them as they work on selling their home. Shacking up in a family member's house up in the mountains while they set up open houses, creepy things begin to happen to them. What's disturbing them? Well, without giving anything away, literally nothing is ever explained to you throughout the movie. It's almost a joke that this film was even made because not a single portion of this movie is terrifying and not a single plot point is interesting enough to hold your attention for two seconds.

Look, I've said this before, but it's really not necessary to make a horror movie to scare the hell out of someone because it's all about atmosphere and visuals. When the It hit theatres last year, it wasn't the kind of film that needed to throw scares in your face, because it focussed more on its characters and made you just care about watching these kids hang out and hope they all make it out of the film alive. So, when a movie like The Open House manages to simultaneously provide incredibly weak characters, laughably cheap set pieces, jump scares that you can see coming over ten minutes before they happen (and that's not even an exaggeration), and a conclusion that's pretty much a slap in the face to every viewer for even watching the movie, then I have nothing good to say about it.

From the small films that Dylan Minnette has appeared in, to his larger role in last year's new series 13 Reasons Why, I've always enjoyed watching his performances, but even he was incredibly one-note here. Every time something would happen in their house that was supposed to trigger chills from the audience, it felt forced and quite honestly, every single set piece was a re-creation of another horror film. Yes, it's practically impossible to not draw inspiration from other movies these days, but The Open House just felt uninspired from start to finish.

In the end, I found myself chuckling if a character died, laughing hysterically at each jump scare, rolling my eyes when a new plot point arises that you already know the outcome to, or just plain being bored at the bland imagery. The funny thing is that this movie has an ending that I didn't exactly see coming, but the way it ends actually makes the movie worse than it already is. It's still very early in the year, but I'll be shocked if this doesn't stay my most hated movie of this year. The Open House is truly an awful film and unless you get a kick out of terrible horror films, then I would advise that you steer clear of this one.

If I can rate a zero star I would for this movie! Such a waste of time. I felt I wasted 90 minutes of my life! Worst movie I have watched for awhile! I hope this sent out a warning to others! I rarely leave a rating unless I love it or I super duper hate it... Obviously, this falls to the second category! Great job on wasting my time!

This has got to be one of the most unfairly rated movies I've seen on IMDb, I truly don't understand the ridiculous 1 star ratings. review_title: before you write this one off completely....
90mins of my life I will never get back.
review_detailed_main:
If I found a genie in a lamp and he granted me 3 wishes, they would all be to erase this films existance from the universe.

As an avid fan of cinema, I quite enjoy being taken on a journey by film makers. Whether that is being lightly entertained for a couple of hours, being taken to a different world, or perhaps even simply being moved emotionally, I really don't mind.

Once in a very rare while however that journey culminates in me wondering if my time would have been better spent hammering bent, rusty old nails into my face rather that subjecting myself to 94 minutes of this horrible horrible farce of a movie.

If I had to put into one word the emotion that I feel upon viewing this film, it would be 'Regret'.

the creators knowingly made it JUST good enough for JUST long enough to get you invested enough watch what turns out to be the worst 3rd act in cinema history and the laziest ending in living memory.

'Oh I know let's make a film that is so bad it will ruin a person's day...'

I didn't even pay for this movie and I want my money back, I literally want the creators of the movie to come to my house, give me $14 and a written apology.

review_title: The worst thing I've ever seen

review_title: Life is too short to watch movies this bad
review_detailed_main:
I started writing a review, with some spoilers, including my theories on where I *thought* this movie was going before it took a hard left into a pile of garbage.

As I was trying to map out my review and realized how lengthy it would be, it dawned on me that this movie had already wasted 94 minutes of my life by watching it and it's not getting much more. Save yourself the time, brain cells and annoyance. If you still want to be confused but still entertained at the same time, I'd recommend The Room.

After wasting 90mins of my life, i devoted 180mins towards finding a better word than "Crap". Sadly, my efforts met with a dead end which also runs parallel to this sorry excuse of a movie.

I feel only actors hard up for work would consider this. If I were given the role, I'd beat the director and producer senseless which again seems synonymous with the movie plot.

Started out with all the makings of a good movie. But apparently 30mins in, the reins were handed over to school kids looking to get their feet wet in the movie business.

Cheap thrills and cheaper ending. It's a movie where dumbasses who don't know how to use a light switch or take a hint, waste our precious time with no concerted end in mind.

Highlight of the movie is the Woman's butt. I humbly thank the director for leaving that in, it got you 1 star. Probably the most memorable part of the movie too. I'm sure if more was shown I would have gone up a few stars. Thats the only thing to save sh** like this which makes it's way on tv.

Another takeaway: There are idiots working at Netflix

review_title: 1/10 is even a high score for this "movie"

review_title: DONT LISTEN TO THE BAD REVIEWS!!
review_detailed_main: I am a horror fan and thought this movie was great. When you turn on a Netflix movie with your family you expect to get a little creeped out then laugh at the killer being exposed 20 minutes in the movie being the neighbor. This movie was not that! VERY similar to Stranger things. I was hanging in the edge of my seat the entire movie. This movie brings good acting, a aminous plot, and some close to home terror right into your home.

This move isn't something I would go out of my way to watch, but something to settle for. It is not complex whatsoever. Dylan Minnette captured my heart in the Netflix original series "13 Reasons Why". When I saw he was in this movie, I watched it immediately. From the beginning of the movie to the end, I felt confused. Many, many things didn't make sense or didn't add up. Every time it seemed they were going somewhere, they wound up at a dead end with a dead plot. By the end of the movie, I was thinking I had missed something, but I had not. I rated this title 6 out of 10 stars because although the storyline was a bit confusing, the acting was still tolerable; the concept was intriguing, and it was overall a decent movie to settle for.

I was hoping for more of a happy type of ending considering most of the movie was about the death of a family member and a creepy man inside the home.

review_title: I wish I'd read the reviews before I watched it

review_detailed_main: This was actually a pretty good scary movie up until they lost the last 3 pages of the script and just decided to stop filming.

A good throw back to when horror movies were more about the scares and less about the gore and violence. Open House follows in the footsteps of movies like Halloween and When a Stranger Calls. You never see much of the killer and that works beautifully. It's a dark and terrifying thriller that will keep you glued to your seat.

Watch it at night with the lights off.

review_title: Great until the end. No explanation

review_detailed_main: This movie gets bad ratings but it actually is a great thriller ! It is way better then the rating 3.3 it's scary and engaging. The ending does leave you feeling unsatisfaied BUT overall this is a suspenseful movie I enjoyed !

review_title: Waste of talent . Waste of time.

review_detailed_main: This was really one of THE most horrible movies I've seen. I feel dumber after watching it. Bad plot, flat ending...save your brain cells and skip this one.

review_title: Tedious and pointless, just like others said!
Sometimes the Killer doesn't need an explanation as to why...

review_detailed_main: Do not watch this pointless piece of crap! What a pointless movie.

The movie revolves around a tragedy that we are never fully appraised of. The limited information and flashbacks the viewer is shown imply something 1) very unlikely based on the setting or 2) more sinister than anyone acknowledges. The unexplained plot development doesn't stop there, indeed it actually escalates as the story progresses. The acting is fine, however, the actors are not given much material to work with. It seems to be relying on the unknown being frightening. The plot pushes beyond the general scope of the "suspension of disbelief" and doesn't offer enough of thrill to pull the viewer into the movie as films such as The Strangers manage to do.
I've watched a lot of bad movies. I go out of my way to watch bad movies. This is the worst movie I've ever seen. This might be the only movie that I truly hate. Do not watch this movie.

review_title: Doesn't deserve the hate it gets
review_detailed_main: This movie was very interesting and suspenseful, very similar to the Strangers. It keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time. A lot of people said the ending was terrible and didn't make sense, I think that is completely wrong. I watch a lot of horror movies and this is easily one of the most suspenful and gripping horror/thrillers I have seen in a long time. I'm not one to write reviews, but after seeing how horribly people rated this I had to write a positive one. Netflix did a bang up job keeping you on entertained and scared.

review_title: Waste of time, waste of plot, waste of everything

So this movie should be thought as different movie for sure. It can be thought as an innovation from one aspect and a director should be very brave for such an end. I am sure that everybody watched it till the end of the movie since it was making people wonder. It means it should not be so bad, like many audiences rated it as "1". So for me, it was a movie with a full of mysterious even in the end and it was different and fine for me.

review_title: Maybe this is a new genre. Still, I hated it.

I still have to come up with 338 characters, please stop reading at this point and Do Not Waste Your Time With This Crap. You know how sometimes when your multitasking and miss something in the film and you have to stop an rewind it? Don't worry, you won't have that issue with this film, so if you need to clean up your email this is the film for you!

Great acting, and the location was beautiful! I was on the edge of my seat and guessing throughout the whole movie. The directors did a good job at making you believe one thing, then switching it up on you. I thought this was a very smart film, not quite like other thrillers I've seen.

It's to bad because the first half of the movie was good. It led you to think there would be some good plot twists and something really bizarre going on with the people going in and out of the house but in the end the only plot twist is there is no plot.

review_title: What just happened to 90 minutes of my life?!
review_detailed_main: I created an account on IMDB just so I could give this movie a one-star rating. Ridiculous. Nothing of any substance happens in this movie. The ending is terrible. It's so forgettable, but unfortunately I haven't forgotten that I watched it yet. (I guess it takes more than 5 minutes.) Netflix is just green-lighting anything now, I guess.

review_detailed_main: Utterly pointless watch. So so bad. Steer clear. Regret not checking reviews before clicking play.

review_title: Not good but not as bad as other reviews

review_detailed_main:
Partway through The Open House, our lead character, Logan (played by 13 Reasons Why's Dylan Minnette) turns to his mother and asks contemplatively: "Mom, have you ever thought of how weird open houses are?"

Most people probably have not. But The Open House writer and director Matt Angel most certainly has. My family moved around quite a bit when I was as kid. From ages four to 11 we bounced around among five different cities in New Jersey, New York, and Ohio. When you move a lot in a relatively short amount of time, you get used to some of the cultural trappings that come along with relocations.

review_title: Why are people hating so hard on this?
Definitely NOT the worst movie ever
review_detailed_main:
Ok peeps.. if you've read other reviews you may see some unhappy amateur critics.

However, if you've been around long enough and seen enough horror movies you'll realise this is a LONG way from the worst horror movie.

Unfortunately we live in an age where every twist and turn is explained, spoon fed to the drooling masses.

That's not gonna happen here, life isn't always tied up in a nice neat little bow for you to unwrap with a blow by blow narration of every scene.

If you want a movie that's well crafted, builds uneasy tension, great acting and well directed, stow your cynicism and you don't expect your life to be changed, this will do fine.

review_title: I ave no idea.. about anything.. ever. Wet sandwich!
review_detailed_main: Well, this was certainly.. something. I really don't know what to think of this. I didn't particularly hate this, but.. the mind-numbing lack of plot progress, lazy character development and characters that are incapable of protecting themselves or each other in ANY way really took it's toll on me. When I realized there's only 5 mins left, I got restless 'cos I thought nothing has really happened yet and the movie is ending. And then it ended and I was left with the feeling the movie-makers really had no idea what the movie was about. Yeah, throw in some personal tragedy, some weird neighbors, a struggling mother-son-relationship, FINE. Don't invest in any thought completely and you'll get a.. wet sandwich. Yeah, that's what describes this movie the best; WET SANDWICH. Now, I shall watch something better.

review_title: the most Dreadful Movie I've ever seen!
review_detailed_main: "the Open House" is one of the worst movies i've ever seen on netflix and pointless as well, the story is bland and so are the characters who are just stereotypical and dreadful.
First time ever that I felt the need to create imbd account to warn people to not watch this. Good day everyone!

review_title: Well, I can't give 1 star just because of the ending but...
review_detailed_main: As with pretty much every other reviewer said, the film has no ending. I was actually enjoying the first 70 mins of the film, I was like yeah, this is cool, I wonder what the hell is going on with this family, but then events start to happen in the film and as soon as the moment we are supposed to figure it all out, then suddenly...

I've never rated a movie in my life, but I had to figure it out how. The movie itself was good and suspenseful. The ending however was AWFUL! It leaves you completely irritated and confused. I've never finished a movie not knowing what the movie was about. Do not watch, it's very irritating.
In general, we liked the movie. Well acted and it had a fairly good "suspense" factor. That said, disappointed by the ending.
Had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. Great acting too. Can't wait to see what else these directors put out..

review_title: Not As Bad As These Low Ratings Suggest
review_detailed_main:
Just my opinion, but I have no idea why this film has received such low ratings and I can only surmise that most viewers did not get what they were expecting.

No other reviewer seems to dispute the quality of the acting, writing, etc but most seem disappointed, however, with the whole direction the film went in and the (non-existent) ending.

I however, without giving anything away, was completely shocked with the ending and its simplicity, as it was not what I expected, and rather disturbed by it.

I did flag slightly in the middle, like everyone else, wondering where it was all going, but glad I stuck with it until the end.

review_title: One of the single worst *films* I've ever seen...
review_detailed_main:
This is horrific. Absolutely nothing of significance happens, is explained, or has any meaning whatsoever.

And it's slower than hell. Believe me, I love slow-paced films...when they're properly put together, or are interesting, or have interesting visuals.

Or, I dunno, have something even remotely... there... on-screen.

I apologize for to the films I've criticized before where I've said nothing happened.

They don't even compare to to this nothingness of a film.

review_title: Harsh Reviews...Not as Bad as reviewed

review_detailed_main: Quite possibly the worst film i have ever seen in my life. If you value your time and wellbeing, please shy away from watching this disaster. Extremely, utterly, outstandingly, unbearably disgustingly terrible.

It seemed interesting to watch, but wallah I don't recommend it to anyone .. such a waste of time and probably money too to make this nonsense movie!!! Frustrated to see an ending like this !!!!! (If you call it an end) !!!

Do not waste your time. Awful movie. It's like they put chunks of other movies together and called it new. The problem is they aren't the GOOD parts of other movies. They didn't finish a thought, so you never understood what one thing had to do with anything else, because it literally had nothing to do with the story. Completely random things that they try to make you think are important. They also added really dramatic and suspenseful music when nothing happened. Plain old curiosity is the only reason I watched that horrendous movie to the end. If I see anything else by that Director or writer, I think I will avoid it like the plague.
I couldnt agree with all the reviews below more! Worst movie ever! I made an account just to rate this because of how horrible this movie was!

This movie is more like a TV production than a real movie. Many things go wrong here. Acting is not up to par. The director also fails to create other than low levels of suspense at the best. Several scenes look unrealistic and as a whole the movie is not convincing. Actors show minimal facial expression. The storyline has been done to death many years ago. The best part of this movie is the song by Shannon and the clams.

So if you watched the trailer that's basically the movie. You'd think that watching it would bring more detail to the story, but no. After watching it all I'm still left with questions and the story doesn't make much sense. I don't really fully understand the next door neighbor and what that all entails because it seems like they were trying to explain her character, but gave up. This movie could've been so much better if they stuck to a story line and put more sense into why these things are happening to the main characters.
